sn22.87:4.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
sn22.87:4.2: Now at that time Venerable Vakkali was staying in a potter’s shed, and he was sick, suffering, gravely ill.
sn22.87:4.5: and in my name bow with your head to his feet. Say to him:

sn22.87:4.8: ‘Sir, please go to the mendicant Vakkali out of compassion.’
sn22.87:4.9: “Yes, reverend,” those monks replied. They did as he asked.
sn22.87:5.1: Then the Buddha got dressed and, taking his bowls and robes, went to Venerable Vakkali.

sn22.87:5.12: “Sir, I’m not all right, I’m not getting by. My pain is terrible and growing, not fading; its growing is apparent, not its fading.”

sn22.87:5.16: “Indeed, sir, I have no little remorse and regrets.”

sn22.87:5.18: “No sir, I have no reason to blame myself when it comes to ethical conduct.”

sn22.87:7.17: They understand: ‘… there is no return to any state of existence.’”
sn22.87:8.1: And then, after giving Venerable Vakkali this advice, the Buddha got up from his seat and went to the Vulture’s Peak Mountain.
sn22.87:8.2: Then Venerable Vakkali addressed his carers:
sn22.87:8.3: “Come on, reverends, lift my cot and take me to the Black Rock on the slopes of Isigili.
sn22.87:8.4: It’s unthinkable for one like me to die in an inhabited area!”
sn22.87:8.5: “Yes, reverend,”replied those mendicants, and did as he asked.
sn22.87:8.6: Meanwhile, the Buddha spent the rest of that night and day on Vulture’s Peak Mountain.
